31.heading: Peirce, Charles Sanders.
31.title: "Reflections of the Cartoon"
31.author: Stephan Packard
31.appears_in: p. 113-125 in International Journal of Comic Art, v. 8, no. 2 (Fall 2006).
notes: Summary (from first paragraph): "I believe that the concept of the cartoon, as originally described ty Scott McCloud, can be better understood by exploring its function from a psychoanalytical perspective, drawing on the design of the psychic apparatus by Jacques Lacan, but also on the semiotic system of Charles Sanders Peirce."

32.heading: Peirce, Charles Sanders.
32.title: "The Semiotics of C.S. Peirce as a Theoretical Framework for the Understanding of Comics"

32.appears_in: p. 193-207 in Comics & Culture (Copenhagen : Museum Tusculanum Press, 2000).

33.heading: Peirce, Charles Sanders.
33.title: "Die Semiotik von C.S. Peirce als theoretisches Rahmenwerk für das Verstehen von Comics"
33.author: Anne Magnussen
33.appears_in: p. 171-186 in Theorien des Comics : ein Reader (Bielefeld : Transcript Verlag, 2011)
notes: Previously published as "The Semiotics of C.S. Peirce as a Theoretical Framework for the Understanding of Comics" in Comics & Culture: Analytical and Theoretical Approaches to Comics" (Copenhagen: Museum Tusculanum Press, 2000).

37.heading: Peirce, Lincoln, 1963-
37.title: "He Told Me To Wait For Your Answer"

38.heading: Peirce, Lincoln, 1963-

Key words: Rings, reciprocation. Call no.: PN6726f.B55 "Rings"

39.heading: Peirce, Lincoln, 1963-

40.heading: Peirce, Lincoln, 1963-

notes: Summary: Angie answers in person, and Nate had been optimistic, but just in case used washable markers to draw all the hearts on the wall. Call no.: PN6726f.B55 "Markers"

115.heading: Pekar, Harvey, 1939-2010.
115.title: Dancing with Your Eyes Closed
115.author: Joe Zabel, Gary Dumm ; introduction by Harvey Pekar.
notes: Summary: "Steve Morton is a morose loner who embarks on an odyssey of the heart, staking his hopes on a new age dance group that promises to be something more. Eyes closed, he navigates the rocky shores of art, religion and sexuality, and discovers within himself a wellspring of vivid inspiration. But with his eyes open, he recognizes the truth about the people with whom he dances."

170.heading: Pekar, Harvey, 1939-2010.
170.title: Harvey Pekar's Cleveland
170.author: art by Joseph Remnant ; introduction by Alan Moore.

publication info.publisher: Zip Comics ; Marietta, Ga. : Top Shelf Productions

notes: Summary (from publisher via SkyRiver): A lifelong Cleveland resident, Harvey Pekar (1939-2010) pioneered autobiographical comics, mining the mundane for magic since 1976 in his ongoing American Splendor series. Harvey Pekar's Cleveland is sadly one of his last, but happily one of his most definitive graphic novels. It combines classic American Splendor-ous autobiographical anecdotes with key moments and characters in the city's history as relayed to us by Our Man and meticulously researched and rendered by artist Joseph Remnant.
